Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: I watched my stepbrother lace up his sneakers, his skateboard already perched at the top of the battered ramp in our backyard. He grinned at me, excitement and nerves flickering in his eyes. “Just watch, okay? I’ve got this.” My heart thudded with worry—he’d never tried anything this risky before, and the ramp was full of cracks and splinters. As his step-sibling, I knew I should stay, keep an eye on him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: Mrs. Alvarez was waiting at the church, desperate for guidance about her failing marriage. As her priest, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to offer comfort and counsel. I felt torn in two, guilt pressing on my chest. If I left, I’d be abandoning my brother when he needed me most. If I stayed, I’d be letting down someone who trusted me with her pain. I stood frozen, keys in one hand, phone in the other, caught between two worlds that both needed me right now.
